awd_titl_txt: A Mixed Up Mantle Beneath Ocean Islands?
awd_abstract_narration:
Basaltic volcanic islands, which occur in all major ocean basins, do not fit particularly well in plate tectonic theory. The lavas from these islands have distinct compositions from basaltic rocks erupted at mid-ocean ridges, indicating the presence of subducted oceanic crust in some of their mantle sources. Current models for the generation of ocean island basalts favor either partial melting of mantle sources with two different rock-types, pyroxenite and peridotite, or sources with only "fertile" peridotite that can readily partially melt. The models are driven by the observation that direct partial melting of recycled oceanic crust cannot generate basaltic compositions. Both source types are therefore thought to form by melting and melding of subducted crust with peridotite in Earth's mantle. How these sources form and melt, in detail, are quite different, with pyroxenite indicating large-scale mantle heterogeneity. An accepted means for detecting pyroxenite is through precise measurement of olivine compositions in basalts. Precious metals such as osmium can also be used to examine between peridotite versus pyroxenite-dominated melting, and the most sensitive method for detecting recycled crustal contributions is from long-lived radiogenic isotopes, like strontium. This work will combine these methods to test whether pyroxenite exists in oceanic island sources through study of two locations where significant recycled crust components are known to exist; Mangaia in the Cook Islands, and the Canary Islands archipelago. New results, which will be partially generated by undergraduate students engaged in research and in the Scripps Undergraduate Research Fellowships (SURF) program, and who will also help publicly communicate the work, will enhance understanding of the fundamental process of basaltic melt generation, and enhance understanding of how ocean islands fit in plate tectonic theory.

This project will examine the role of pyroxenite-peridotite or fertile peridotite melting in the generation of ocean island basalts (OIB) through examination of two key OIB localities. The first locality is Mangaia (Cook Islands), where long-lived radiogenic isotope (Sr-Nd-Os-Pb) variations will be coupled with olivine compositions to examine a location without a strong pyroxenite melting signature but that does have a strong recycled crustal signature (HIMU). The goal of this task is to quantify mantle source composition for an extreme recycled endmember composition in OIB petrogenesis. The second task is to evaluate pyroxenite-peridotite contributions to Canary Islands that also have a HIMU signature. Studies have argued for pyroxenite contributions, but with different endmember compositions. Here, new high-precision electron microprobe data will be collected for olivine grains in lavas from the islands to combine with Sr-Nd-Os-Pb isotope variations and highly siderophile element abundances. With these data, it will be possible to discriminate between depleted or enriched pyroxenite sources and to investigate if high pressure-temperature melting of fertile peridotite might offer an alternative. Research will include integration of undergraduates and underrepresented minorities who will also be engaged, along with the PI and graduate student, in outreach events that will take place in the San Diego region and in the Canary Islands, and through participation in organized STEM events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the NSF project "A Mixed Up Mantle Beneath Ocean Islands?," our goals were to understand why ocean island volcanoes, like those that occur in the Canary Islands, Hawaii or Iceland, produce lava compositions that are so distinct from one another, at a chemical level.

Several ideas have been proposed to explain these different lava compositions. Some scientists have suggested that bits of material that were originally on Earth's surface were taken back into the deep in a process called subduction, eventually finding their way back up at volcanoes. It has been suggested that these materials get squeezed and heated into distinct rock types in the deep earth. These are known as 'recycled materials'. Other scientists have argued that what matters are processes like how deep and how much melting occurs that causes the distinctions.

In the project, our original intent was to study lavas that has been erupted long ago on ocean islands like the Canary Islands. While we were doing this, however, nature did was it does best, and not one but three eruptions took place in Iceland, the Canary Islands and Hawaii. The first began - and essentially continues today - on the Reykjanes peninsula of Iceland in early 2021. We were able to work with colleagues from Iceland and Sweden to rapidly analyze these samples. Later that year (September 2021), the Tajogaite volcano of La Palma in the Canary Islands was born, and with colleagues from Spain, Sweden and Germany, we were able to analyzed those lavas as well. Finally, about a year later, in November 2022, Mauna Loa came to life once more. Collaborating with the USGS, we have been able to analyze those lavas too.

Due to the rapidly changing nature and excitement surrounding the project, reacting to volcanic events across the globe, we were able to expand our research goals. In addition to answering some of the major questions in our research, we were able to take a time series approach to understand volcanic processes. As we and collaborators were collecting freshly erupted lavas everyday from eruptions in Iceland, Hawaii and the Canary Islands, we could use these to understand much more than we could otherwise have done.

Key results from our work are that processes like the depth and extent that melting occurs beneath volcanoes is very important. Volcanoes like Tajogaite in La Palma produce magmas that feed lavas which come from much less extents of melting than say Mauna Loa or the Reykjanes. This has effects on lava chemistry that need to be separated from recycled materials.

Despite this, we see strong evidence for recycled materials present in some ocean islands too. This is especially true for La Palma and the Canary Islands in general, where mixing between the recycled materials, the normal mantle material (the mantle in the main silicate reservoir between the crust that we live on and the metallic core in the centre of the Earth) and the extent and depth of melting all play roles in affecting magma - and hence lava - compositions. 

Addition of time-series analysis of the Icelandic, Canarian and Hawaiian volcanic events provided an unprecedented analysis of how lava compositions change with time during volcanic eruptions. We were able to show in Iceland and the Canary Islands that the magma compositions can change quite radically with time during the eruption, giving us clues to both the magmatic plumbing system beneath the volcanoes, and to contextualize what magma compositions of older rocks that we do not see erupting (i.e., old lavas that we collect long after they were erupted) might mean.

Research in this project has been led by undergraduates, graduate students and post-doctoral scholars. In particular, post-doc Dr. Willie Nicklas pioneered some of the studies we did into olivine (a green mineral similar to peridot) in the lavas. Post-doc Marine Paquet studied samples of the mantle to understand the nature of a mixed up mantle from an alternative perspective. Graduate students Brian Oller, Diana Brown, Eric Snortum, Emily Rhoads, Hunter Edwards (continuing) and Aliyah Stark (continuing) have all conducted work to address the key goals of the study.  

Perhaps most significantly in the project, many of the graduate students mentioned above (Snortum, Rhoads, Stark) were undergraduates at UCSD brought into the research due to the excitement surrounding understanding volcanism. Undergraduates including Haider Rangwalla, Bryce Elsner and Veronica Yonce were also all involved at various stages in the work. In particular, undergraduate Savannah Kelly was strongly engaged in studying the Iceland eruption of 2021 and 2022 and is second author on a paper to be published very shortly. In short, this project has helped train and engage a host of students, while also enabling us to address key goals and also to recognize new and key questions surrounding volcanism and the deep Earth.
